respondent.name: JEFFREY A. BEARD, SECRETARY, PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: We will now hear argument in Rompilla against Beard. Mr. Nolas.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, you're asking us, I suppose, to make a rule that you have to get paper records.  We've seen a number of capital cases, you know -- as you know.  This counsel seemed to me to be quite articulate and -- and had a very sound theory of -- to argue to the jury for mitigation.  It didn't work, of course.  I -- I just don't know what constitutional rule you want to ask us for, that you have to look at record evidence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, you had three forensic experts, outside experts, and they didn't seem to think the papers were relevant either.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, counsel -- counsel did make use of several relatives of the defendant who testified.  I -- I think weren't there about four relatives who testified?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And he talked to all of them and talked to the defendant as well.  So would a reasonable person think that's enough to find out family history and -- and the concerns that you had?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That -- that seems to me an -- an extraordinary non sequitur.  I don't understand.  They didn't want to deal with it because they thought he was innocent.  I -- how does that make any sense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What she testified to makes no sense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, the -- the portions of his life history that -- that are the most appealing are the portions from his youth, before he went into the -- into the juvenile institutions, and they were certainly with him during that period.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Let me -- let me take you back to the -- to the experts.  You say he did not specifically ask the experts to go -- to go into his childhood problems.  You know, I can imagine when the expert comes on the stand, the first question being asked is, now, Mr. Expert, were you told by counsel to look into the childhood problems?  You know, as though counsel were planting in the expert's mind what the expert should say. Page 7What would anyone who hires a psychologist or a psychiatrist -- what would anyone expect him to look into in -- in determining whether the person is -- is mentally injured but -- but the childhood?  Do you really think counsel could not have expected with total assurance that these people would do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Nolas?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Wasn't it the case that those experts were hired not primarily or even secondarily for mitigation purposes?  They were hired in connection with the possibility of a defense at the guilt stage, number one, that he was insane at the time he committed the crime, in which case what he was when he was a child would be irrelevant, and number two, that he was presently incompetent to stand trial.  So they were asked specifically to inquire into his present mental situation, and their testimony was relevant to the guilt phase of the trial.  So that's the instruction.  Naturally they -- what -- why are we engaging you?  We're engaging you to tell us do we have a basis for an insanity plea, do we have a basis for an incompetent to stand trial plea. Page 8

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Was there any indication that after the guilt phase was over and before the sentencing phase began -- I take it it was just a matter of hours or almost days till the sentencing -- till the sentencing phase began.  Was there any contact with the psychiatrists or with experts after the sentencing phase and the -- pardon me -- after the guilt phase and before the sentencing phase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought what you just quoted said that they -- that they would intend it to be used in the mitigating phase.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Doesn't -- doesn't all that bear upon mental infirmity at the time of the offense? Isn't the reason that -- that one considers these factors mitigating is that they reduce the guilt at the time of the offense? I -- I thought that that's the whole --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We -- we just let him off because we're -- we're sympathetic to his present state? Page 10I thought that mitigation means that it reduces the guilt of the offense at the time that he commits it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Mr. Nolas, you haven't mentioned it, but didn't one of the three experts suggest that there be a -- a follow-up inquiry into the -- the abuse of alcohol by the defendant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: My understanding is that nothing was done in response to that.  Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Which -- which you're saying they did not do.  I mean, just to get it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Nolas, there were some records that the prosecution sought and used.  Was it -- the records that were in the very courthouse.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What did the prosecution use? The fact of early -- early conviction and the details of the crime.  Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And what would they have found?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Nolas, are you telling us that all that information would have -- was in the file that described the -- the criminal history that the prosecutor used in his case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And they didn't even look at that file?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is this the document that's on the lodging at page 31-34?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you want us to adopt a constitutional rule that at least in Pennsylvania counsel have to consult these -- these records --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- as a constitutional matter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So your -- your answer is yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You want a constitutional rule that in Pennsylvania counsel must look into these records.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about a rule that says you must consult the file of the case that's being used by the prosecutor to produce seriously aggravating circumstance, at least where that file is readily available, and you Page 15 must follow up indications in that file that suggest a significant mitigating defense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that's nothing special to Pennsylvania if you know that the prosecutor is going to use a certain file.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What -- what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: For what purpose did the prosecution use the files?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Use them for -- he did use them for aggravation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In -- in what respect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I don't like to either direct your own argument or the questions from my colleagues, but the Simmons issue here --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- it seems to me is important and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Wiggins.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Wiggins.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If there had been no questions from the jury, it seems to me that you wouldn't have had an argument at all because the counsel was allowed -- the counsel was allowed to argue this to the jury and did argue it to the jury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Would you -- would you agree that but for the questions from the jury, Simmons was complied with?  The counsel argued the point to the jury --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- without being -- without being contradicted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No.  So now -- now we have a Page 19situation where the case, by my suggestion in any event, was properly presented to the jury, and the only question is what the constitutional obligation is once the jury brings in a question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, it didn't expressly.  I mean, there -- there were arguments about his behavior, but the problem I think we have with the Simmons claim here is that the Kelly case had not yet been decided, and you now have the AEDPA situation of trying to show that the State court's resolution was objectively unreasonable. And prior to Kelly, that's a pretty tough road for you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And what's the best argument you have that future dangerousness was an issue?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, of course, that also bears on the -- on the fact of his depravity, that he was just -- he just didn't learn.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I don't know if that's necessarily future dangerousness or -- it's equally blameworthiness.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, that goes to his blameworthiness. He didn't learn anything in prison. I -- I suppose future dangerousness is -- in a sense is always in question, but I think our precedents say it has to be specifically or -- or clearly implied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can you imagine any capital case, if we accept that argument, in which future dangerousness is not at issue? Because whenever you show the depravity of the defendant, what a horrible crime it was, you're going to be able to make the same argument. Any jury is going to be frightened of this man and think he's going to be dangerous in the future. If that's all -- if that's all that Simmons means, we should just say in all capital cases, you assume that it's at issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that seems to be not what we've said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But -- but that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that goes -- I -- I would make that argument to show how -- how horrible this crime was. He killed this person specifically in order to prevent testimony, which makes the -- the crime worse. I don't think it necessarily goes to future dangerousness any more than any of the element -- other elements of depravity or -- or the horribleness of the crime goes -- goes to future dangerousness.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and you -- you expect us in all future cases to read the prosecution's argument and Page 23 -- and say, well, has it gone over the line from just his depravity into he's future -- you know, he's going to be dangerous in the future?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think that puts too much of a burden on -- on the Federal courts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: This -- this prosecutor also said, before he got into isn't it frightening, I'm not Page 24asking you for vengeance.  So if he's not putting it on for vengeance or the bad acts that he did, then what else could it be?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How about justice?  I mean, is that the only alternative to vengeance, is -- is future dangerousness?  I don't think so at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that there was no problem in any State but Pennsylvania because now all of Page 25them -- when the jury wants to know does life mean life, the judge says yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, you may reserve your time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Ms. Zapp. Page 26

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, do you -- do you take the position that the -- that the argument that the prosecutor makes has got to refer explicitly to future dangerousness, a kind of talismanic words criterion so that we'll have a bright line rule and everyone will know where -- where he Page 27 stands?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No. But has -- has the prosecutor got to use a phrase like future dangerousness or a synonym for that phrase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- if we -- if we don't adopt that kind of explicit words criterion, do you deny that the -- that the argument that the prosecutor made, particularly the -- by -- by introducing the -- the evidence of -- of the prior crime for purposes of the aggravating factor and the argument that he made about how the defendant had learned from his prior crime -- do you -- do you deny that -- that those were in fact, not with the talismanic words, but that those in fact were -- were arguments that suggested future dangerousness? Page 28

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But I -- I don't see how the -- I -- I guess my -- my point is I don't see how you can avoid it.  The -- the argument -- I think we would all agree that the argument was this person has committed repeated crimes.  We're asking you to bear that in mind for the purposes of applying one of the three aggravating factors.  In the course of committing repeated crimes, he has learned from past mistakes; i.e., he knows this time not to leave any witnesses. How can you divide the tendency of that argument, repeated crimes for purposes of aggravation, from the tendency of that argument to say repeated crimes in the future if he gets a chance?  This is the kind of guy we're dealing with.  How can you draw that line?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but this is -- this is a special case. This is not a general argument to the effect that this is a very bad person and we can expect bad persons to be bad in the future. This is a more specific argument. This is an argument that says he's now done it twice. This is the second crime and he's getting better at it as he goes along because now he kills the witnesses. This isn't just generalized badness. This is criminal repetitiveness. It is recidivism. And it seems to me that that is a much clearer argument. It is much closer to the explicit argument that he will do it in the future.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ms. Zapp, I guess -- I guess Page 30 I'm confused about your case. I had thought that you were not arguing that Simmons requires a talismanic word or even that it requires much more than existed here. I thought what you were arguing is simply that Simmons could at that time have been interpreted that way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you're not -- you're not making the argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you're saying the argument could have been made at -- at the time of this trial --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- and before our later jurisprudence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And why would that argument have been reasonable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: In other words, why -- why would we -- why would it be reasonable to assume that this Court had -- had established a constitutional rule going to jury instruction that rested on a kind of talismanic criterion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What -- what specific words in -- in the concurring opinion gets to the talismanic point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And -- and you're -- you're depending on the word, in effect, argue as -- as requiring -- or as -- as being a basis to say the argument has got to use talismanic words.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're saying it has to be Page 32 argued.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not -- not just intimated, not just suggested, but the jury -- you have to argue that this person --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- is dangerous in the future.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's a reasonable interpretation of it I would think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And on that interpretation, why wasn't it an argument within the meaning of -- of your point, when the prosecutor here got up and said, isn't it frightening, he has, in effect, learned from his past experience, now he knows enough to kill the witnesses?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Wasn't that an argument which -- which goes to future dangerousness?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Ah, but what immediately follows -- first he said it's absolutely frightening twice.  But there is one difference, one major difference, and the difference is that he has learned to leave no witnesses.  That is tightly connected.  He says this is an absolutely frightening crime, but there's something more. He's learned not to leave any witnesses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I know you want to get to the other issue in this case, but let me ask you.  You've, I assume, read these cases.  In -- in other States where this instruction is given, is the prosecutor free to say, well, sure, there's life without parole, but that can Page 34change?  We don't know what the law will be like 3 years from now, 5.  Have there been any problems along that -- along those lines?  Have there been any problems generally in giving this instruction to the jury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that explains why your State is the only holdout.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you a question about the competence of counsel issue?  One -- I'm -- I'm very sympathetic to the problems of busy lawyers who have so much to do and they're preparing for a penalty hearing. But one -- one aspect of this case -- I hope you'll comment -- and that is, the fact that the prosecutor had told the defense they were going to use certain aggravating circumstances, and the files in those -- relating to those circumstances were available in the courthouse.  And as I understand -- and you correct me if I'm wrong -- counsel did not examine those files, and had he examined those files, he would have opened the door to a wealth of information.  Isn't that a fairly serious mistake by the lawyer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, maybe they -- assume that's all true.  They thought they knew everything --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- they needed to know.  But still, if you say to me I'm going to put on certain exhibits, A, B, and C, and the defense says I'm not even going to even take a look at them before you put them on, I find that quite unusual.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: They thought they had -- it was reasonable when they, on their own, suspected that this man might not even be competent at the moment to stand trial, that he -- that they might have a -- a basis for an insanity plea, that it was reasonable for them to rely just on what he told them without looking at the record that was in the prosecutor's hands?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I understand that.  You're Page 39 repeating that point which -- so I might ask this question on this very point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Could -- could I find out what she said came late? I -- I didn't understand. You said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- it came -- what came relatively late?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Came up late.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My question is this, that I take it on page L31 is the record that existed in this horrendous rape '74 case with Jo, whatever, the woman, the bartender. And the prosecution was making an enormous amount out of that. We've just heard about it. That's true, isn't it? Am I right about the case? Have I got that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.  This is -- I'm thinking of it correctly, that this is the record in the case that the prosecution made a lot out of.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm back with Justice Stevens then and I wonder how it's possible a lawyer wouldn't look at the record in that very case if only to see if the prosecutor is characterizing the situation accurately.  And had he done so, he would have seen on the next page, alcohol problems.  He would have seen a complete list of siblings, and he would have seen, four pages later, a one-page list of criminal behavior with identification of crimes that took place when he was a child.  That's all true. Now, if he had then noticed these early criminal records when he was a 17-year-old and simply gotten the record in that one, he would have come across the document that is on page L44 and L45 which says, among other things, Ronald comes from the notorious Rompilla family. And then there is a list of why they are called the notorious Rompilla family which is fairly horrendous. Now, I do not understand how any person, getting the first record, wouldn't have been led to the second, and I do not understand how any person who read pages 44 and 45 of the second would not have thought what the Page 41siblings are telling me is wrong.  I better go check on a few more siblings who happen to have their names and addresses here right in the pieces of paper he's looking at.  And he would then have discovered this absolutely horrendous background that Judge Sloviter mentions.  So I do not understand why that one incident, leaving aside all the other ones, but I do not understand why that one failure to consult the record that is being used by the prosecutor horrendously against him is not a failure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: This sounds to me like a constitutional argument for serendipity.  You're held to be negligent if you don't look at the record for -- for one purpose and -- and discover by accident something that's there for another purpose.  I -- I don't know what the logic of that is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do you agree with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.  We don't -- you agree with that or not? Page 42

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You either agree with Justice Kennedy or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You do agree.  All right.  Now, if you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, my question, obviously, is, is not the reason that you want to examine the criminal record in the case that is being used horrendously against your client is to find out both as to what happened at the time and also the background that would be relevant in respect to your client?  For example, alcohol abuse, which happened to be checked.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Zapp. Ms. Lovitt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But a rap sheet and so forth will not have normally what this person is like.  You're dealing with a client who has serious problems of some kind as the crimes themselves reveal.  They're terrible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And -- and so I -- don't you think it's a reasonable -- or do you think it's a reasonable constitutional requirement to say that where cases of prior history of the client are being used by the prosecution to say what a terrible person he is -- and he may be -- that you -- the -- the lawyer in a capital case at least should look at the court records in that case to learn something about what this human being is like and why?  Because court records, but not rap sheets do contain that kind of thing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Experts that were hired primarily to say what is his present mental condition, not what happened in the past.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What was the primary reason that those experts were engaged?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The primary reason.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where -- where is this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought it was not Page 46contested that in fact the primary reason why these doctors were engaged was that the defense attorney wanted to see if there was a basis for a plea of insanity.  He wanted to see if there was a basis to claim that his client was incompetent to stand trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And Dr. Gross is the one who -- who in his report suggested a follow-up on alcoholism I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And one way, at least a kind of a threshold step to follow up on alcoholism, would have been to look at the -- the personal history report in the file of the prior case.  If they had done so, they would have found something on that subject. So even -- even if we forget the question of the -- the scope of the expert's original brief and we look to Dr. Gross' suggestion and we look to the failure to look in an obvious place, i.e., the -- the personal history Page 47 report and -- and the case file, which the State said it was going to use, don't we have a problem with competence of counsel?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: The -- the two other psychiatrists or psychologists?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Wel, were they -- were they hired to -- to look into alcoholism?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Would you tell me again? I'm -- I'm just afraid I missed it before. What is your justification for failing to look at the -- at the criminal files?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So even if they did, would it -- you still think it would be prudent not even to look at the file?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, they didn't have as much as they would have had if they'd looked at the file.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Do you agree with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, I understand that. I'm just -- I'm just asking you whether, as a matter of routine preparation for a contested hearing, it is not the duty of counsel to take -- at least glance at the exhibits Page 49 that the other side is going to offer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You're saying they did get copies of the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What is the it? What is the it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But not everything that was in that file.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was a lot more than just the transcript of the proceedings in that file.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, the serious question to Page 50 me is -- is -- in many of these cases which we see, there are horrendous child abuse histories, and child abuse is a terribly difficult thing to get at and it's something that might not convince most juries of anything because they're all over the place. But nonetheless, counsel should have to make a reasonable decision about whether to take the child abuse route or to take some other route. And would it cause constitutional harm, that is, would it cause harm even from a prosecutorial point of view, if you just said, well, you should follow up and look at records of prior cases being used against you to see if you get a clue there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But Strickland was about a strategic decision to pursue one kind of defense rather than another. The Government's brief, I must say, was candid Page 51and, I think, useful.  I'm talking about footnote 5 on page 22 where you say the Federal public defenders in Federal death penalty cases -- they get a mitigation specialist and the mitigation specialist, of course, gets records.  What records?  Exactly what we're talking about in this case.  Gets records, birth, schools, social welfare, employment, jail, medical, and other records. And here, not one of those -- not one -- was sought.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: About what records to go to, and here they went to none.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Lovitt. Mr. Nolas, you have about 4 minutes left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Only? Only? Only?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think it's uncontested that all three looked into that, but the point that has been made is that the last two went beyond that. Do you disagree with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Nolas.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The case is submitted.
